Award.AwardTitle: Nanoscopic Understanding of Protein Transport and Structure Dynamics in Charged Gels for Protein Chromatography

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1032727
Carta

Intellectual Merit

The broad objectives of this research are a fundamental understanding of protein transport in charged gels for protein chromatography and the development of new matrices incorporating flexible polymers in a rigid support matrix. Although protein diffusion in neutral gels is generally well understood, our basic knowledge of how adsorbed biomolecules diffuse in
oppositely charged matrices is currently extremely limited. New matrices obtained by incorporating charged dextran polymer grafts in porous supports and exhibiting unique protein transport properties have been developed in prior work. However, the underlying transport mechanisms are unknown, which prevents the development of optimized materials and their description with fundamentally sound models. Thus, the proposed research has three main goals:

- To determine the structure and dynamic behavior of dextran-grafted matrices by dynamic light scattering (DLS) in order to understand fluctuations and structure dynamics of polymer chains in these systems.

- To study protein transport in these materials at the nanoscopic scale using single molecule tracking techniques to determine the mobility of individual protein molecules in matrices functionalized with charged polymers.

- To develop molecular models at multiple length scales to describe the structure and dynamic behavior of polymer functionalized matrices as well as their interactions with proteins, and use these results to elucidate the experiments in goal 2 and construct physically accurate conceptual and phenomenological models for practical rate predictions.

Collectively, the components of this research will provide a yet unrealized level of understanding of transport phenomena in these complex media, the basis to develop new, more effective materials, and models to aid the design and optimization of chromatographic processes.

Broader Impact:

Advances in the biomedical sciences have raised expectations for new biologics-based drugs for the prevention, treatment, and cure of serious diseases and, indeed, new protein based biopharmaceuticals are having a huge impact on the lives of people. However, separating and purifying these biomolecules is complicated by their slow diffusion, which currently limits the performance of industrial biochromatography. The proposed project has the potential of
transforming downstream processing of biopharmaceuticals by introducing new, more effective stationary phases as well as an unprecedented level of understanding of transport phenomena, thereby enhancing process understanding and control as well as reducing dramatically the time and effort needed for process development and design.

Research and education will be integrated by incorporating the results of this project in educational modules for college level students, by strengthening the education of graduate students with synergistic activities in experiments and molecular modeling, and through a Short Course in Protein Chromatography for industry professionals held annually at UVa. Outreach will include developing laboratory demonstrations for use in sessions for the Upward Bound program for high school students, by facilitating participation of minority undergraduate students in our Short Course, and by recruiting graduate
students from underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has uncovered some of the fundamental underpinnings of protein transport in charged gels and other matrices used for the purification of industrially relevant proteins. The key question addressed by this project is whether molecular mobility is preserved when protein molecules are partitioned matrices obtained by grafting charged polymers to a rigid porous support matrix. Experimental results obtained both from macroscopic measurements and by confocal laser scanning microscopy, show that under certain conditions protein mass transfer rates are substantially faster than could be predicted for ordinary diffusion in a porous matrix without polymer grafts. These results are attributed to the dynamic behavior of the polymer grafts and to the reversible nature of the protein electrostatic interactions with these materials. Using either mixtures of antibody charge variants, different antibodies, or mixtures of native and PEGylated proteins, this project has demonstrated that transport in these polymer-grafted matrices occurs by mechanisms that are quite different compared to those observed for diffusion in porous media. Specifically, multicomponent protein transport in grafted matrices is dependent on the direction of transport as a result of coupling of diffusion fluxes.

Microscopic models have been developed to describe transport in these systems and have been successfully applied to the prediction of the separation performance of chromatography columns based on such grafted matrices. The molecular modeling component of this project has allowed us to test our hypotheses regarding protein transport mechanisms by probing the dependence of the dynamic behavior on molecular details. We can use this molecular modeling approach to show how changes in properties in the polymer and on the surface can affect both binding to the support matrix and to the polymers, as well as diffusion through the entire system. Additional work helped explain how different molecular simulations methods affects the predictions of the rate molecular movement, allowing us to better answer the main questions of this study. Semi quantitative agreement between predictions from the molecular models that we have developed and experimental data has been obtained by employing a multiscale modeling approach, using molecular simulation details to provide the inputs to modeling on larger time and space scales. This multiscale modeling approach is now being used to explore the purification of larger and more complicated proteins, as well as to understand how to modify the polymer matrix to further improving the speed and capacity of these chromatographic materials. Finally, a single-molecule-tracking microscope has been developed to probe the ranges of molecular motion that have been deduced from microscopic measurements and are predicted by our molecular models.

The project has also had a strong educational component. In addition to undergraduate and graduate student training, a short course in protein chromatography, attended by practicing scientists and engineers, has been offered multiple times. The course emphasizes protein transport mechanisms in chromatography columns and has allowed the dissemination of the information generated in this project directly to industrial practitioners helping them understand and model the factors that limit industrial protein purification processes and helping them make decisions regarding the selection of chromatographic resins for process use. The project results impact the industrial production of biopharmaceuticals designed to treat serious conditions such cancer, autoimmune diseases, and serious infection, by allowing faster, safer, and less costly process development and operation.
